If you have been diagnosed with MS I would like to give you some advice concerning things I have found out through having this disease for 13 years ( officially, but actually longer undiagnosed ).
Take a vitamin D3 supplement during late autumn ( fall ) and early spring and ALWAYS IN THE WINTER MONTHS.
Also take a zinc supplement and high dose vitamin C to help strengthen your immune system.
During a good summer, try to catch a daily dose of full sunlight for 15 minutes.
If offered a flu vaccine BEWARE - it may give you a prolonged mild flu/cold symptom for a long time as it used to with me, which is why I don't have one.
I take 'Copaxone' ( Glatiramer Acetate ) which does NOT weaken your immune system as do some of the other MS drugs. Please research how your drug therapy affects you and don't blindly accept a flu vaccine without finding out about any side effects first.
Eat healthy food and cut down on the junk.
And remember ; that vitamin D3 ( D3, as opposed to plain D ) CAN help you, as even my own specialist ADMITTED to me that she believed it HAD helped in my case.
It isn't expensive and will not interfere with any drugs given to you by your MS specialist.
In summer it is free - just go out in the sun.
Best wishes to all the fellow sufferers!

Very recently diagnosed and I'm a strange case. I started having simple partial seizures at 18. My gp thought they were panic attacks until my mum reminded him that he diagnosed quite a few members of my family with epilepsy. He then referred me to a neurologist, which would have taken a few months to see if it weren't for one morning mum had to take me to a medical assessment unit after having loads of seizures, which to her looked a lot like TIAs. My neurologist sent for me soon after, gave me an MRI and evoked potential (to find my trigger, it is stress). I had to go into hospital for a couple of days for monitoring, blood tests and a lumbar puncture. Had to get tested for something called CADASIL (genetic :( ). Came back all clear, apart from altered wbc. Now, I have a clinically definate diagnosis, half of my face with altered sensation, painful leg spasms, some difficulty speaking and living on meds for my seizures. I'm 21 now and studying to be a nurse. It can be done, and I've always been told that I'm so strong for continuing as I am. All the MS warriors are strong, even at your weakest. (And the patients I've met that have MS are the most down to earth, genuine people I've met.)

I have MS and I know why I contracted it. Lack of sleep = immune system unable to repair itself = immune system went wonky = MS.

I drove a taxi in 2004 and 2005 in Toronto. Driving a taxi is tiring and entails long shifts i.e. 12 hours everyday 7 days a week. Having done this for two years and maintaining a bit of a life meant i ran on very little sleep, sometimes as little as 2 hours a night. I was 24 then and thought I could pull it off. Little did I know sleep is essential to a healthy immune system. At the end of 2005 I had my first episode of double vision which lasted just two weeks. I did not bother going to a doctor until my second episode in 2009. That is when I got diagnosed.

Have you guys seen this? This is HUGE & comes from the Lyme world. Dr. Alan MacDonald has found filarial worms in 9 out of 9 MS patients & another 80 year old autopsy of a person who had Lyme Disease for 20 years & MS for the last 10 years of his life.

He found that the nematode worm causes the destruction in the brain & is migratory & causes a wake of destruction in its path. That is why sometimes the MS symptoms are migratory & one can bounce back, as the brain heals itself after the migration of the worm in the brain. These filarial worms are found in ticks & can also be passed by mosquitoes & other biting insects.

He has also found Borrelia burgdorferi (the main agent of Lyme Disease) that lives INSIDE THE WORM as endosymbionts. In his past work he has also found 100% of Alzheimer's/Dementia patients have the Borrelia bacteria in the amyloid plaques of Alzheimer's brain autopsies. He has done his work with new 21st century DNA Probing, which binds to species specific DNA like a lock & key. He has also found Borrelia miyamotoi in both Alzheimer's & MS patient samples & they do not test for this newly discovered species that also cause Lyme.

Another group of scientist have also discovered 2 more new species of Borrelia that cause Lyme or Lyme-like symptoms & both of these are also never tested for in the ELISA & Western Blot!!! This is HUGE, HUGE, HUGE!!!!

I have had many of the symptoms of MS. I have seen over thirty physicians before i finally got a correct diagnosis. I had brain fog, neurological issues, nerve pain, body aches and pains, chronic fatigue, muscle weakness, and more. I have learned that what many western medicine physicians diagnose as MS is actually chronic lyme disease. If you are not getting better, get a lyme test done. I would suggest only Igenix labs for a more accurate diagnosis and then find a qualified dr of integrative medicine. Also, watch the movie, Under My Skin. It's enlightening. My dr told me that the majority of people with MS , really have lyme disease. Good luck and I wish you well.

I was diagnosed last month when I went to hospital with a bad case of optic neuritis. 
It felt alien to me as I don't remember being admitted in hospital before. I have always been a healthy person. I train almost every day . Swim, run, lift, eat a very clean diet. I don't drink or smoke, 25 years.  I thought I was invincible!
Anyway, I had an MRI done, it showed a number of lesions and the neurologist told me I have MS. I had no idea what it was at the time but later found out that it is a chronic debilitating disease with no cure.
Been really anxious/depressed for the past few weeks. Worried about what the future has for me. Can't sleep, can't concentrate at work, lost a lot of weight.
I am feeling better now because family has been really supportive but I don't think I will ever accept it.
I am going for a 5 day infusion in few weeks. I am really hoping these drugs work so I can spend more quality time with my little son and my lovely girlfriend.
Stay strong and never lose hope fellow MSers.

I am using Rebif 3 times a week, i used to have a much larger dose. the depression and emotions that comes along with ms are sometimes very severe, along with severe depression comes suicidal thoughts. i live in the dutch caribbean so i also have a perscripion of medical cannabis witch i have used in episodes and cases of extreme brain pain, partial paralysis and alien arm.. i felt pushed in the corner, only negative feelings and i remembered the relief the cannabis has brought me when i was in a episode. so i began using it on a daily basis, smoking,eating,making tea. the cannabis i receive here in bonaire is hi with cbd and lo with thc, so it doesn't get me hi. i have found that yoga a few times a week, a healthy diet and constant use of cannabis my alien arm is gone, numbing and partial paralyses is 99% gone, episodes only last 1-2 days instead of 3-4 weeks and are much less frequent, emotions and depression are much more manageable. many people with ms have a problem remembering, the genaral thought process is messed up. but just as important as remembering is, forgetting is exactly important. when i smoke or eat a cookie, i can forget and go places witch are peaceful and dont have to worry. the fatigue is also helped because my body gets a chance to relax, maybe more importand then my body is my mind and it also gets a chance to relax, to slow down, to stop the rush and it does make it "ok" much more tolerable. life with ms is bad enought, life with ms without cannabis is hell. this morning i will focus on positive things, i will make a fruit shake no sugar no milk. i will do 30mins yoga. and i will smoke 1 gram of cbd canabis. if i am up for it, maybe later today i will go swimming or to the beach. something to remember for everyone with ms. exacly that, you have ms, ms doesnt have you. one love.

Hiccups are merely where your diaphragm starts to "spaz". Your diaphragm is randomly going off which is the reason why it is impossible to know when the next hiccup will come. The so called "remedies" are just things that don't make you better,where you are tricking yourself into thinking your getting better. After a while your diaphragm stops "spazing" and then your back to normal. By the way.... I'm only 12 and in the 7th grade. I knew this, and you,, did not. This is sad my friend.

MRIs are very important to the diagnosis, they alone do not rule out other disorders (Lupus, Lyme's Disease or even a T.I.A (mini stroke). Your neurologist needs to follow it up with a Lumbar Puncture where a sample of spinal fluid and a blood sample are drawn and then sent off to a specialty lab to have the proteins compared. If the difference in quantity of proteins is large, then diagnosis can be confidently made. My difference was 18 with 8 spots in my MRI. I was diagnosed December 2009.

Scientists do not actually know why we yawn. Because yawning is contagious, it therefore must be that yawning is advantageous to the species. Therefore, it has been possible for scientist to theorise about yawning.
Humans are not the only species who yawn so scientists looked at some birds and found that by yawning, they inhaled more air and cooled their brains. Thus, it would be advantageous to yawn so that the body can work at its optimal temperature.
Also, to get more oxygen into the body.

We don't. We yawn when our brain needs "refueling". Basically more oxygen. We usually yawn when we're over worked or under worked. For example, you could be doing a lot of studying and yawn a lot. Not because you are bored, but because it's just a lot of work. Also, if you stay up too long and get tired, the brain needs more compensation for the more hours it's a lot more active. Your brain activity goes down when you're asleep.
